title: The Heart of a Steward
sub_title: The Wisdom of Old Man Hemlock
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock, as the townsfolk affectionately called him, wasn't known for grand gestures. He lived a simple life, tending to his small but vibrant vegetable garden with a quiet diligence that bordered on reverence. He wasn't a wealthy man, but his table was always laden with produce, and he generously shared his bounty with neighbors in need. One particularly harsh summer, a blight struck the region, devastating crops. Many farmers, driven by desperation, hoarded what little they had left, hoping to sell at exorbitant prices when the famine worsened. Hemlock, however, did something different. He opened his garden to the entire village, allowing anyone to take what they needed, free of charge. Some scoffed, calling him foolish. They accused him of throwing away his livelihood. But Hemlock simply smiled, pointing to the intricate irrigation system he'd meticulously crafted, designed to conserve every drop of water. "God provides," he'd say, his eyes twinkling. "We are merely stewards of His gifts. If we hold onto them too tightly, they wither and die. But if we share them, they multiply."

That year, Hemlock's garden, though depleted, survived the blight better than most. And more importantly, his act of selfless sharing sparked a wave of generosity throughout the village. Those who had hoarded began to share, realizing that true wealth lay not in possession, but in community. Old Man Hemlock taught them a valuable lesson: Stewardship isn't just about managing resources; it's about recognizing that everything we have is a gift, meant to be used for the benefit of others and the glory of God. It’s about recognizing that we do not own, but we merely borrow.
image_description: A flourishing vegetable garden with ripe tomatoes, zucchini and peppers, bathed in the warm glow of the late afternoon sun, with hand-carved signs indicating "free for the taking".
insights: The parable of the talents (Matthew 25:14-30) illustrates the importance of good stewardship. Each servant was entrusted with a different amount of talents, and their master expected them to use those talents wisely to generate more. Those who invested their talents were rewarded, while the servant who hid his talent was condemned. This parable teaches us that God expects us to use the gifts and resources He has given us for His purposes and the benefit of others. 1 Peter 4:10-11 emphasizes that 'Each of you should use whatever gift you have received to serve others, as faithful stewards of God’s grace in its various forms.'
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the countless gifts you have bestowed upon me. Forgive me for the times I have been selfish and failed to use my resources wisely. Help me to recognize that everything I have is a gift from you, meant to be shared with others. Give me the wisdom and courage to be a faithful steward of your blessings, using my time, talents, and resources to serve you and love my neighbor. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What gifts and resources has God entrusted to you? How can you use those gifts more effectively to serve others and glorify God? Are there any areas in your life where you are holding onto resources too tightly? How can you practice generosity and stewardship in those areas?
